They use of combination of motion tracking (actigraphy) and heart rate data to estimate your sleep stage at any given time. Different sleep stages are known to have different heart rate and activity patterns - on average, in deep sleep people have lower heart rates and less movement; light sleep, higher heart rate and more movement. It’s important to remember these are estimates of sleep stages, not direct measurements. While significant progress has been made in recent years, there’s been very little clinical research published on the accuracy of sleep tracking from wearables, particularly beyond simple motion/actigraphy, so take your results with that in mind.
